comments.commentBody:
five, Wunderkind, David Steinberg, is definitely a FRENEMY of the People of WP, who we'll keep a sharp eye on, till that lovely day when we can all rejoice in saying "I knew him when...ECCE HOMO!"

Warren, make no mistake about it, five! Hehehehe
Is the NYC sure that baby Loren in the photo is four months old? He looks awfully big and well developed for that age.

Good comment, but I just saw Tamerlan Tsarnaev's wife (now widow) on TV in a hijab. Many people will equate that with his becoming "more religious." Perhaps wrongly, but they will.

I am happy to hear ordinary Muslims say this has nothing to do with Islam, and I believe that to be true, but it would be nice to hear it more often from prominent religious leaders. Could some famous Muslim religious leader please go on TV and say "It is NEVER acceptable to set off a bomb aimed primarily at killing civilians. EVER." Please?

This' not the first time this has happened. Imagine if there IS another bomb, should they make the judgment to put THEIR career on the line to save hundred of others?, or should the police wait and regret forever afterwards.
@JD, or he might have taken the guns kept for self-defence and used them on the homeowners, killing them.
Actually, it began with them obtaining some pressure-cookers.
I would bet even money that not only are there others connected with this, but that this whole attack was Stage 1. Law enforcement has to know this.

"This guy ain't from the hood." !?! What exactly do you mean by that? You have no idea what kind of neighborhood these young men experienced in their home country so I really don't understand! They came here as refugees from a war torn nation. He has much more phenotypically in common with most others I've read about who have committed similar mayhem amongst Americans - he is young, male and white - perfectly placed within the majority of Americans.
Are you suggesting that this is expected behavior from people who live in the American "hood" - whatever you conceive that to be? You are exposing your personal prejudices, Rockreef. Shame on you for suggesting that a "hood" is a breeding ground for such mayhem.

Its hard to believe that he did it on his own. Especially since he was a guy that goes to college and hangs out with friends like normal people. Why would he go from normal guy to a super crazy maniac and go grand theft auto on a cop and then run from cops, who have way more training than this kid ever had. It doesn't make since for a random guy who's suppose to be a bookworm, to just pick up a gun and suddenly he's a marksman shooter, who apparently was capable of holding his ground against an entire force.
It doesn't add up.
I think there's more at play. Just sayin, this guy ain't from the hood. Lets just put it that way.

Since your from Japan you have no idea what has happened in this country since 9/11. The US government can now deem a US citizen a (terrorist combatant) doing this makes the individual a citizen without a country and hence Miranda is no longer needed , that individual can also be held indefinitely without being charged and tortured if needed, this is now the law in the USA.

Potty training if in fact they are using a "potty." Holding the baby over a sink or bowl in someone else's home, or peeing and pooping behind a tree in the park or on the ground at the playground seems not to be "communicating" appropriate hygiene to this baby or other children learning to use the toilet. At what age do we make the transition from tree or bowl to toilet? Not sure the 3 or 4 year old is going to remember not to eliminate at the park. I'd be more open to (other people) doing this if they were using the toilet and not my kitchen sink. And I'm sorry, but disease is spread from feces, even tiny ones. Parents and caregivers of babies given polio immunization were warned to carefully wash hands after changing diapers: the virus could be contracted this way. And gosh, what about e coli and norovirus? Sorry, but I'm thinking that the playground and parks will be not a happy place after the "EC'd" babies are done. Cloth or Pampers, put a diaper on that baby....

Have you realized how many people from NYC are commenting how they think this is a ridiculous idea? Calling the practice of a small number of people from NYC hardly makes it an "NYC thing" when it appears many more from NYC would never consider it!

What do you want public policy to say to these people sinking into insanity?

"Assault us!"?

And then make an E-bay business out of selling the weapons to do it?

Yes, people kill. All the more reason guns should not be in the hands of people.

Less (or no) guns, equals less killing.

Leave guns only in the hands of those who are trained and paid to protect us.

It did NOT end peacefully! Did you read nothing? I am as horrified and saddened by what happened in Boston as anyone, but this cannot be called a peaceful outcome. One young man dead, another even younger man near death. And we don't know why.

Gratifying that it ended peacefully and positively and not with more killing, if anything good can be found in this. So much for banning assault rifles, though I am not a gun owner. Bombs don't kill people, people kill people. We can all use some sleep.
If not guilty he certainly gave a convincing impression of a guilty mass murderer.

Maybe you missed some critical parts of the story?  Did you miss the part where they described having photographic proof of them on video approaching the bomb site and putting down the bag, and then leaving?  Or the part where the man who tragically lost BOTH of legs called the police while still in the ICU to tell them he locked eyes with the suspect moments before the explosion?  Or the shooting of the MIT police officer?  The photos of him at the ATM pulling money out of the stolen credit cards of the man they had kidnapped/carjacked....the same man who told police they CONFESSED the crime to?  What about pressure-cooker bombs being thrown at police during the car chase?  Strangely, coincidental, no?  How much evidence do you need to arrest someone?  Do we need to witness every act personally before we believe it?  The bad guys will always go free if so.  Innocent until proven guilty still holds.  He could have surrendered peacefully but chose not to.  He has the right to be heard.  All accounts of those who knew him say he was a good man.  Let the court decide.
A common misperception, perhaps, but the expression "innocent until proven guilty" refers to the presentation of evidence in a trial.

Guilty until proven guilty.  That's American justice post 9-11.  Every victim of the marathon bombings, everyone in Boston, and everyone in the U.S. should be praying that this boy is guilty.  If he's not, we should be praying for our souls.

Orders to stay inside and not to let anyone in (including family) except government officials, unmarked black ops vehicles.  I hope you have the opportunity to review how this is all run.  I am not criticizing what was done today, but I wish one-tenth of these resources were focused on the banks and Wall Street.
And your point would be what, exactly? Not capable of shooting people, not capable of setting of an explosive device, not capable of being a threat to public safety, what exactly?  19 is not a child!
She's been interviewed by media.
"Injure"? Is that a polite word for murder?

The social, political part of me feels terrible for the victims of the bombings on Monday. However, the human part of me feels terrible for these boys, specifically the younger one. I live in Cambridge, MA and will be attending the high school that he went to. Cambridge is a close, respectful community, and the high school's motto is "opportunity, diversity, respect". From what I've heard from the suspect's teachers and friends on the news, he was a smart and nice kid. I can't imagine what he might have been through in the past few years that would make him want to injure so many people.

Too bad. He lost all the good life he had here in comparrison to the one he would have had in Russia. He was raised very well with the welfare his parents received while he was growing and his mother too was not satisfied with that. She started being a shoplifter at cloth stores ( what an example). Even though he is young, I have no compassion for him because I have seen the horrific maiming and killing he did, for no apparant reason. Now he can be happy between 4 narrow walls the rest of his life. When he chose to set those bombs  against  American citizens, including children to destroy & kill, then he truely does not deserve the Miranda Rights read to him. As citizens, we have that right, he lost his.

What do you think they're doing in the dark of night? They are planning MORE bombs for tomorrow( or Today, since it's been past midnight). No one just drives around with grenades, pressure cookers, explosive, and machine guns. It's clear that IF the police hadn't acted just now, and HEROICALLY so (3 wounded, at least 1 had died); the price we have to pay today would be ineffable.

Next time you begin to feel sorry for him, think of the scores of people who will bear scars forever, and the many who will use prosthetic legs. Think of the dead. Think of the fear that will recoil through our society for years to come. Think of the trauma so many have suffered. Can you?

I have no pity for him whatsoever. He deserves none. I do not care what his reasons were, why he did it, who else he may blame. "Smart and nice" chose an evil path, and that's a one-way route for him. He will be tormented forevermore, never a good night's sleep. Fine by me.

I live in Somerville, near Porter Square.  People like HKC are why I love this place.  Of course, we are all saddest for the victims.  But that these two young men, at least one with apparently a lot of promise, would choose to do such a heinous thing is a sad story in and of itself.  If we are too angry and blind to think about why things these things happen, how can we ever hope to prevent them?

The "human" part of you feels sorry for the suspects. But only the "social, political" part of you feels sorry for the victims? The victims don't merit your human part? And, what is your "social, political" part anyway?

I can comprehend wondering why the suspect turned to violence--how a seemingly nice kid changed. Even feeling regret that he did change. But, the fact is that he did. The change certainly deserves study to understand the process and to attempt to develop preventive strategies so it is not repeated. And, sure, to discover if there were some sinister abuse occurring in his life that could shed light on what happened.

You do say you will be attending his high school. So, perhaps you are identifying with him because of that. But, although you are young and not a parent, try to identify with the parents and sisters and brothers of the people who died. The parents, spouses, brothers and sisters of those who are injured and changed forever--many with lifelong physical, mental and emotional disabilities. Shouldn't your "human" side feel sorry for them?

And, think about what it would be like if your sibling, if you have one, were killed or hurt. Or your parents or grandparents. Or best friend. Certainly you would want someone's human side to feel sorry for you.

I hope you will more clearly reflect on this and that your "human" side can feel sorry for the victims here; they deserve a lot more than a " social, political" glance.

The social, political part of me feels terrible for the victims of the bombings on Monday. However, the human part of me feels terrible for these boys, specifically the younger one. I live in Cambridge, MA and will be attending the high school that he went to. Cambridge is a close, respectful community, and the high school's motto is "opportunity, diversity, respect". From what I've heard from the suspect's teachers and friends on the news, he was a smart and nice kid. I can't imagine what he might have been through in the past few years that would make him want to injure so many people.
They obviously were not the sort who think things through, or they would have anticipated the tawdry outcome and abandoned their project at the conjecture stage.

Fantastic, amazingly quick work by the FBI and the Massachusetts police! I'll be interested to hear the details of how they tracked down the suspects.

I'm still somewhat worried that all this was meant to be a diversion from a second, even more horrific terrorist act. The Tsarnaev brothers seemed, at several steps along the way, to be *trying* to get caught. They don't bother with disguises, or even wide-brimmed hats? They don't even bow their heads as they walk down streets that are not only fitted with multiple security cameras, but are also being filmed by television professionals and millions of amateurs? They don't immediately board a plane or train? They (possibly -- I've also heard that it was an unrelated robbery) hold up a 7-11? They carjack a car and tell the victim straight up that they're the Boston marathon bombers?

It's true that, in a well-planned and coordinated set of attacks, the second shoe should've dropped by now. But perhaps something delayed it. In any event, there may have been others in on the plot who have yet to be discovered. For these and half a dozen other reasons, we can't let up our guard at *any* sensitive potential US targets around the world.

And particularly, on behalf of all those in NYC and its environs, I hope they stay on heightened alert at Indian Point for at least the next month.
Now is NOT the time for another Jack Ruby.

I find it amazing that these culprits were caught so quickly. Let this be a deterrent. Am very proud of Cambridge, Boston and all of U.S. Just another way that digital and social media have totally changed our world. Criminal apprehension will never be the same again.

Your comment immediately brought to mind the irony that this very week, almost simultaneous to these tragic events our Senate, which no longer seems to be 'ours', voted down the mildest possible gun control bill. It is unfathomable and utterly sickening. Wrenching, actually--that young policeman in his patrol car might have not been killed and another officer seriously injured. What is it going to take? We must vote these people OUT. Very, very sad.
I might put it that this act of violence gives us an opportunity to try out a different reaction to terrorism from the one we came up with after 9/11.

A neighbor in Great Neck in the mid sixties was from Scotland . When she went home to visit her mother sat the baby on her lap on a potty. No kitchen bowls, etc. and no dumping inany sinks. The waste went into the loo.

I'm sure there are chamber pots for sale in the NYC area possibly in a Euro type baby store.
Fair is three games for Juninho for violent conduct red card and one match for Neilsen for simulation (which ain't gonna happen)
Stupid play by Junhino.  But Neilsen was simulating being hit in the face.  He wasn't.  So if there is any review then Neilsen ought to get suspended too.
GREAT! So well that most of the Wednesday fans that I know, albeit online, want him to stay! The comments on the message board have been overwhelmingly positive, if not gushing.
How well has he actually played?
